revised_title: Vegetation and Flora History of Widdybank Fell and Cow Green Reservoir Basin, Upper Teesdale
tldr: This study investigates the stratigraphy and pollen analysis of peat deposits on Widdybank Fell and the Cow Green Reservoir Basin in Upper Teesdale. The research shows that peat formation in the area began during the late-glacial period and continued until recent times, with a brief interruption between 10,000 and 8,800 years ago. The late-glacial vegetation was gradually replaced by woodlands, which never developed a closed canopy. From 5,000 years ago, these woods were replaced by blanket bogs and grasslands on limestone. The presence of rare species in the area, such as Gentiana verna and Dryas octopetala, is confirmed through pollen analysis, demonstrating their persistence in the region throughout the post-glacial period.
